properties.title: The Struts Project TODO List for Version 1.0

section.name: Introduction
section.p: Application frameworks, like the applications we build with them, never seem to be completed. The following are the remaining work items before Version 1.0 of Struts can be released.

The TODO list tasks are divided into functional areas that correspond to the major components of the Struts Framework. References in square brackets are the Java package containing the corresponding source code.

info.p: Omnibus task list for items related to the Struts Documentation, which do not have direct relationships with code bases.

task.name: Users Guide
task.info: Update the Struts User's Guide to reflect Struts 1.0 APIs and design patterns. Split into multiple files as required for good organization. [STRUTS-DEV, Gidado-Yisa Immanuel, 10/31/2000]

info.p: Document specific installation instructions, problems, and/or user experiences on a variety of application server and servlet container platforms.
Integrate Ted Husted's web page containing available resources about Struts into the standard documentation application.

task.name: Struts Tutorial
task.info: Integrate Struts tutorial provided by Bluestone. [STRUTS-DEV, Michael Schachter, 01/02/2001]

info.p: An example web application utilizing the Struts framework and custom tag library.
Add support for switching Locales on the fly to the Struts example application.
This is the core controller servlet, with support for the developer's action and form bean classes, plus the supporting data structures.
Create developer guide documentation for this package, in file "package.html".

task.name: Command Token Support
task.info: Support the ability to include unique tokens in forms used to detect duplicate or out-of-order submissions. Will probably also require additions to the <html:form> tag. [STRUTS-DEV, William Jaynes, 12/07/2000] [STRUTS-DEV, David Geary, 12/22/2000]

info.p: Review framework-wide use of features that have now been deprecated.

The Digester package supports scripted firing of "rules" based on matching a particular pattern of nested XML tags. Among the predefined rules that can be utilized are rules to create new objects, set bean properties from the contents of attributes, or call arbitrary methods with arguments based on the XML content being parsed. A common use for this technology (illustrated in the Struts ActionServlet), is parsing configuration files and building corresponding object trees.

This tag library contains basic tags useful in manipulating JavaBeans and their properties. It includes support for getting and setting bean properties using simple, nested, and subscripted accessor expressions.

This tag library contains tags useful in preparing web applications that use HTML forms as their primary mechanism for user data entry, as well as support for internationalized and localized applications.

Convert all Java classes from package org.apache.struts.taglib.form to package org.apache.struts.taglib.html. Copy "struts-form.xml" to "struts-html.xml" and update Java class names. Leave the old "struts-form.xml" file (deprecated) with new class names to ease conversion.
This package contains a variety of utility classes useful within Struts as well as in stand-alone applications.
